Topic.Title: AMZN is doing $62 billion of revenue and makes no PROFIT. None, Nada, Zip.

Message.Msg: With major retailers price matching, local pickup and a physical store with customer service (and in the case of BBY, Geek Squad technical support to install and service big ticket electronic items), the value proposition is diminishing for Amazon quickly. That's why it is trying so hard to do everything inlovled in the sale but not claim title to evade/avoid taxes (finance inventory, maintain inventory, draw website visitors with unprecedented advertising expenses, process transaction, pick, pack and ship... but still claim it isn't sold by Amazon).

Message.Title: Bears, let me explain it to you
Message.Msg: All the crowing about "huge internet sales". Don't you understand, this is already in the price. Stocks discount future results. In the case of Amazon, future sales have been discounted many times over, with the absurd current and forward PE. Amazon has yet to demonstrate it can monetize sales to build profits. Let us say it will---how many years of profit gains would it take to get 'Zon down to a rational PE level? Even if we assume the BEST case for future profits (I don't), Amazon would probably have to fall below $125 for a correct discounted price. But what if the profits DON'T materialize? Amazon could easily fall below $100. Amazon is clearly in "bubble valuation" territory, as absurdly overvalued as any of the examples last seen right before the 2000 "tech wreck". Save yourselves and lock in current price. Sell.

Topic.Title: Bears, let me explain it to you

Message.Msg: Correction--"bulls". The bears get it.

Topic.Title: Gap Up and Run?

Message.Msg: The Internet shifts the bargaining power from sellers to consumers through comparison-shopping that lets consumers get better value per dollar spent—Black Friday online transactions increased by 30 percent, while the average price per ticket was down 11 percent, according to Chasepaymentech. That explains the razor-thin profit margins of on-line retailers. Amazon’s operating margin, for instance, is 0.93 percent compared to 5.94 percent of Walmart. This means that transaction volume is the name of the game in online shopping.

Topic.Title: Tech predicted iPad mini would have Siri

Message.Msg: The article (like all media articles on Amazon for now) leads with Amazon having the highest YOY growth of online retailers. But, that growth IS slowing (49% to 43%) despite massive investment in revenue growth: 1) loss leaders stacked on loss leaders -- Kindle, Kindle Fire, Prime; 2) several more new products than last year via full kindle platform refresh; 3) a vastly more aggressive TV advertising campaign -- I've seen far more Amazon commercials than Google, Apple or WalMart. That has to be adding up. As I said, eBay has done NO advertising that I've seen. Yet, its growth accelerated from 12% to 36% YOY, but wasn't included since it is a "marketplace" instead of a retailer. A marketplace whose merchants don't yet have to collect taxes -- which is why Amazon is pushing the Main Street Fairness Act while trying to evade taxes that it has agreed to collect by financing and maintaining inventoring, driving web traffic through advertising, processing orders, and fulfilling them yet claiming they are not "sold" by Amazon... But really, despite the massive differential in growth rates which happens to correlate the Amazon having to collect taxes in many states, believe the analysts who tell you that it doesn't matter...

Topic.Title: Tech predicted iPad mini would have Siri

Message.Msg: The significant point is that eBay marketplace (where merchants DO NOT yet have to collect taxes in many states where Amazon does) saw YOY growth accelerate significantly while Amazon's dropped despite massive investment in loss leaders and advertising campaigns...

Topic.Title: Kindle gets hosed by iPad big time

Message.Msg: If you dig down to the underlying report from IBM, you will also see that online Department Store sales growth was very strong, stronger than most other categories. Price matching? ****** Holiday sales growth was led by several industries which include: - Department stores continued to offer compelling deals and promotions that drove sales to grow by 16.8 percent over Black Friday 2011. - Health and Beauty sales increased 11 percent year over year with consumers once again choosing to pamper themselves this holiday - Home goods maintained its momentum this year, reporting a 28.2 percent increase in sales from Black Friday 2011. - Apparel sales were also strong this holiday with Black Friday numbers showing an increase of 17.5 percent over 2011.

Topic.Title: Kindle gets hosed by iPad big time

Message.Msg: I meant to say as strong as other categories... The point is that "online" is not cannibalizing traditional retailers to the extent that is being sold... Online is still only 10% of total and Dept. Store online basically expanded at the same rate as other online... Furthermore, Dept. Store online average transaction size increased much more rapidly than the other categories.... Another sign that traditional retail is getting better at fighting showrooming on big ticket, high value density items...
